Authors:
Malte Ebinghaus, Michael J Wingfield, Dominik Begerow,
Wolfgang Maier
Title: The genus Ravenelia (Pucciniales) in South Africa
Keywords:
rust fungi, Phylogeny, CO3, Diversity, Ravenelia moloto
sp. nov., Ravenelia molopa sp. nov., Ravenelia modjadji sp. nov.,
Ravenelia doidgeae sp. nov., Ravenelia spinifera sp. nov., Ravenelia
dumeti sp. nov.
Abstract:
The genus Ravenelia represents the third largest genus of
rust fungi. Yet to date there has been no attempt to study its phylogeny
utilizing molecular phylogenetic techniques. This study was focused on
South African representatives of Ravenelia with newly collected
specimens analysed using 28S rDNA and CO3 sequence data. The results
resolved six phylogenetic clades corresponding to the South African
species, one species that represented a distinct lineage and additional
two groups having an exclusively neotropical origin. By linking these
clades to their morphology and life-cycle characteristics, it was
possible to interpret the outcomes in terms of their evolutionary
ecology and to consider their biogeography. We found, that convergent
traits in Ravenelia are misleading when drawing conclusions about
monophyly in Ravenelia. But host associations, the ability to induce
aecial galls as well the development of two-layered probasidial cells
represent useful criteria for this purpose. Furthermore, the Senegalia-
and gall-inducing Vachellia-rusts in South Africa appeared to have
evolved different ecological strategies to disperse and persist in the
South African Savanna biome. Six novel Ravenelia species were discovered
and described. Furthermore, five species represent new reports for South
Africa, species descriptions were emended for two taxa and a new host
report emerged for R. inornata.
